definition: to look at each other in dismay (idiom)
flour/noodles/(of food) soft (not crunchy)/(slang) (of a person) ineffectual/spineless
face/side/surface/aspect/top/classifier for flat surfaces such as drums, mirrors, flags etc
flour/noodles/(of food) soft (not crunchy)/(slang) (of a person) ineffectual/spineless
face/side/surface/aspect/top/classifier for flat surfaces such as drums, mirrors, flags etc
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)

sentences.english: knees. Jeff and Flora looked /into/ each other’s faces with a look of fright.
sentences.chinese: 杰夫和福罗拉面面相觑，惊恐不已。

sentences.english: We looked not know how to answer.
sentences.chinese: 大家面面相觑，不知道该怎么回答。

sentences.english: The guests looked at each other.
sentences.chinese: 宾客们都不禁面面相觑。

sentences.english: We gaze at each other as dumb animals gaze at human beings.
sentences.chinese: 我们哑口无言，像愚笨的动物痴望人类一样面面相觑。

sentences.english: All the young mice were silent, and only looked at one another.
sentences.chinese: 所有年轻的老鼠都安静了下来，大家只是面面相觑。

sentences.english: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told that he need not stay.
sentences.chinese: 吉英和伊丽莎白面面相觑，便打发那个堂倌走开。

sentences.english: Jasper and I looked at each other.
They all looked at one another. It was the preacher from the True Believers, John Garrison.
sentences.chinese: 众人面面相觑，原来是那位实信会牧师，约翰格里生。

definition: lit. dumb as a wooden chicken (idiom); fig. dumbstruck
agape and tongue-tied (idiom); at a loss for words/gaping and speechless
overwhelmed with shock, horror or amazement/dumbstruck/aghast
to be surprised/to be amazed/to be stunned
to be shocked/to be appalled/to be terrified
